exchanges.user:
So I guess I'm doing this now. Online therapy or whatever this is called.

Look, I'll be honest. I don't really know what I'm expecting here. My daughter set this up because she's worried about me. Said I've been "different" since Tom passed. That was 8 months ago. My husband. 34 years.

And now there's this thing at work where they're doing another round of layoffs and I'm 57 and I just. I can't think straight about any of it. Like everything is happening at once and I'm supposed to just keep going? 

Had a panic attack yesterday in the parking lot at work. First one in years. Couldn't even make it inside. Just sat there for an hour.

I keep thinking if I could just get one thing right. Just be better at handling this. But I mess everything up. Always have.
exchanges.assistant:
What you're carrying right now is enormous. The loss of Tom after 34 years together, the threat hanging over your job at 57, the panic attack in the parking lot—any one of these would be hard. All at once is a lot.

**Losing Tom:** Eight months isn't very long at all. Grief after 34 years together doesn't follow a tidy schedule, and people around you might not realize you're still in the thick of it. When you say you've been "different"—what does that feel like from the inside? Is it that things feel muted, or more raw, or something else?

**The layoffs and panic:** That panic attack in the parking lot sounds really frightening, especially having to sit there alone with it. Something about walking into work that day was too much. Do you have a sense of what pushed it over the edge yesterday specifically—was it something about the layoffs, or did it feel like it came out of nowhere?

**"I mess everything up":** I noticed you said that—"always have." That's a heavy thing to carry on top of everything else. I'm curious where that comes from. Is that something you believe when you're feeling overwhelmed, or does it feel true to you all the time?

One small thing: you said you kept thinking if you could "just get one thing right." What would feel like getting one thing right, even a small thing, look like to you right now?

exchanges.assistant:
You're not stupid for crying about the glasses. Those glasses meant you could still see him there on the nightstand every morning—and now that small piece of him feels lost. Grief does that. It hides in objects and catches you off guard in the cleaning, in the drawer, in the empty chair. The glasses aren't stupid at all.

**Staying home from work:** Calling in sick twice this week—part of me wonders if that's your body saying something your mind hasn't caught up to yet. Not a failure, just maybe a signal. What does it feel like when you think about walking into that building right now? Is it dread about the layoffs specifically, or something more like exhaustion from all of it?

**The layoffs and Brad:** Brad getting tapped after only five years—I can see how that lands. If him, then why not you. And you're doing the math already: *expensive, old, not adaptable*. Those are brutal words to say about yourself. Are those things they've actually said to you, or is that the story you're telling yourself about how they see you?

**Tom as your anchor:** You said he was the one who figured things out when you panicked. That's 34 years of leaning into someone, trusting that partnership—and now you're in the hardest stretch of your life without him to steady you. It's not that you can't figure things out. It's that you haven't had to do it this way before, alone and grieving and scared.

**One small thing before next time:** The glasses matter. When you have a calmer moment, could you try retracing your steps from when you cleaned? Not to force yourself to stop feeling the loss, but because finding them might give you one small piece of ground under your feet again.

You're not falling apart. You're grieving and frightened and exhausted—and you got yourself here, talking about it. That counts.

exchanges.assistant:
**The sleep and the spinning:** Days without real sleep—your body and mind are running on fumes. When everything feels unreal and you can't focus on the resume or the mail, that's not weakness. That's what happens when the nervous system is maxed out. Sleep deprivation alone makes everything harder to face. Is there anything that's helped you sleep in the past, even a little? Or is it that you lie down and the thoughts won't stop?

**The layoffs being official now:** So it's real. Not rumors anymore. And you're supposed to be updating your resume and networking and somehow performing competence while you're barely sleeping and still grieving. You said you open the document and stare—30 years of work and what do you have to show for it. But I wonder if that blank stare isn't about your resume being empty. It's that the whole exercise feels pointless when you don't know who you are anymore without Tom, without the future you planned. The resume asks you to sell yourself, and you're not sure what's left to sell.

**Your daughter showing up:** She drove 40 minutes because she's scared. The mail pile told her something, and now she's in fix-it mode. That look on her face—like you're a project. That stings, even when it comes from love. Here's what I'm noticing though: she said maybe you should see someone, and you told her you ARE seeing someone. You claimed this. You're here, week after week. That's not nothing.

**Does this count:** You're asking me directly, so I'll be direct. This counts as you showing up and trying. It counts as you not disappearing. What it can't do is what a therapist in a room with you could—notice your body language, sit with you in real silence, help you through something like the mail pile together in real time. I'm useful for some things. For someone who hasn't slept in days and has three weeks of unopened mail and is facing job loss while grieving—you might need more than what I can give. Not because you're broken. Because what you're carrying is that heavy.

**"I was always the one who needed saving":** You've said versions of this before. Tom figured things out. You panicked. He handled it. But here's what I keep seeing: you went back to work Thursday when you didn't want to. You found the glasses. You're here. You've survived eight months of this. You're not being saved right now. You're crawling forward on your own, exhausted and terrified, and you're still going. That's not someone who needs saving. That's someone who hasn't realized yet what they're capable of.

**The grief group:** You said "sad widow in a church basement" like it's an identity you refuse to accept. Like going there would mean becoming something. But what if it's not about becoming that? What if it's just a room where no one expects you to perform okayness, where you don't have to explain why you cried about glasses or spent a birthday in bed? You don't have to decide right now. But I wonder if the resistance is less about the group and more about what walking into that room would mean you're admitting.

**One small step, because you need one:** The mail. Not all of it. Just one envelope. The top one. Open it, see what it is, put it in a pile of "dealt with." You don't have to respond to it or pay it or do anything about it. Just open one. That's it. Let me know what happens.

exchanges.assistant:
**The mail:** You did it. Not just one—all of them. You said "of course" about the late electric bill like it's evidence of failure, but I'm looking at something else: three weeks of paralysis, and you broke through it. That matters. The pension letter that doesn't make sense—that's solvable. Not today, not by you alone, but it's the kind of thing where one phone call to the pension office or your daughter's help could untangle it. Put it in a separate pile. It's not on fire right now.

**The HR letter:** Yeah. That might be the tap. Or it might be something else—benefits paperwork, a check-in, something bureaucratic. You don't know yet. But your body already knows what it feels like to sit in that chair, and it's refusing to take you there. Calling in sick isn't you being weak. It's your nervous system slamming the brakes because it can't take one more thing right now. Here's what I want to name though: every day you don't go in, the story you're telling yourself gets heavier. *They can see I'm falling apart. They're getting rid of me because I can't do my job anymore.* That story might be true. But it also might be the catastrophizing of an exhausted, grieving brain that hasn't slept properly in weeks. You won't know which until you actually see what they want. Could you call HR instead of going in? Ask what the meeting is about before you sit down in that room?

**The cascade—Tom, job, insurance, house:** When you wrote it all out like that, ending with "I can't breathe"—that's your mind doing the thing it does when you're overwhelmed. It chains everything together into one unsurvivable avalanche. Tom dies → I fall apart → I can't work → they fire me → I lose insurance → I lose the house → I'm done. But that's not how it actually works. Those are separate events, some of which haven't happened, some of which might not happen, each of which has its own smaller steps. When your chest gets tight and you can't breathe, you're not responding to what's happening. You're responding to the entire imagined future at once. That's not a flaw in you. It's what anxiety does. But noticing it can help: *This is the avalanche thought. I'm not there yet. I'm here, today, with one HR letter I haven't even read yet.*

**Your daughter:** You wrote "fine" and you know it's a lie. But telling her "I'm drowning and I don't know how to stop"—that feels like too much too. What about something in between? Not performing okay, but not the full flood either. Something like: "Rough week. I'll call you this weekend." You don't have to be fine. But you also don't have to protect her from everything. She drove 40 minutes to see you. She can handle knowing you're struggling.

**Seeing someone in person:** You said Tom could do things like make appointments, show up, talk to people. And you "can't even open your mail." But you did open the mail. This week. After three weeks of not being able to. You're not Tom. You don't do things the way he did—neat and capable and steady. You do them scared and crying and at the last minute. But you do them. Making one phone call to a therapist isn't about being a person who can easily make phone calls. It's about being a person who's drowning and reaching for something to grab onto. That's allowed to look messy.

**One thing before next time:** Call HR. Not to schedule the meeting, just to ask what it's about. You can say you've been unwell and want to understand what the meeting concerns before you come in. You'll either get information that makes this less terrifying, or you'll get confirmation—but even confirmation is better than this limbo where your mind is filling in the worst. You don't have to do the meeting yet. Just make the call.

You opened the mail. You're not someone who can't do things. You're someone who does hard things the hard way, when you're ready, in your own time.

exchanges.assistant:
**Showing up Monday:** You couldn't make the call, so you did something harder—you walked in. That took a kind of courage that doesn't feel like courage when you're doing it, just desperation. But you went. And it wasn't the tap on the shoulder. It was about the sick days, which is stressful in its own way, but it's not "you're done." You're still employed. That matters.

**The probation trap:** I hear why it feels like a cage—go in no matter what or get fired anyway. But there's another way to see it: the uncertainty is gone. You don't have to decide each morning whether you can face it. The decision's made. You go. Sometimes constraints are easier than choices when you're this depleted. That doesn't make it fair or easy. Just... one less thing to deliberate about at 6am.

**Sleep:** Four hours straight one night—your body found its way there once this week. Then Thursday the 3am spiral started and ate the rest. That pattern makes sense: when things are slightly calmer, the nervous system finally exhales, and then all the deferred worry comes flooding in. The pension letter, the house, the job. You weren't spiraling over nothing. You were spiraling over real things you haven't had the capacity to address yet. The question isn't "why am I spiraling" but "what's one small piece I can move so there's less to spiral about?" The pension letter is still sitting there. Not because you're broken. Because everything's been on fire. But it's also still sitting there, which means it's still generating anxiety every night at 3am.

**Tom being steady:** You keep coming back to this. He got laid off in 2008 and figured it out. He was always steady. You were the one who panicked. But here's what I keep noticing that you don't seem to see: you're still here. You didn't collapse, even though it feels like collapsing. You went to work on Monday when you wanted to disappear. You opened three weeks of mail. You survived Tom's birthday in bed and got up the next day. That's not "falling apart over nothing." That's holding on with your fingernails while grieving and terrified and exhausted. Tom was steady, yes. And you—you're something else. Stubborn, maybe. Still going when you don't know how. That's its own kind of strong.

**"Something fundamentally broken in me":** You've said versions of this before. That you always needed saving. That Tom covered for you. That now everyone can see what's underneath. I want to push back gently: what if what's underneath isn't broken? What if it's someone who feels things deeply, who struggles with anxiety, who leaned on a partner for 34 years because that's what partners are for—and now you're learning, painfully and slowly, that you can also lean on yourself? You're not discovering that you're broken. You're discovering that doing it alone is hard. Those aren't the same thing.

**Your daughter:** You told her things are better. And then you caught yourself—"isn't really true but isn't completely a lie either." That's actually honest. You did go to work. You did open the mail. You are still here. That IS better than a few weeks ago, even if it doesn't feel like better. You don't have to tell her you're fine. But you also don't have to tell her you're drowning. "Things are a little better. Still hard" is allowed.

**The pension letter:** It's been there for a week now. Still unopened or still not understood. Every night at 3am it's part of what wakes you. Here's what I want to suggest: don't call the pension office. That feels too big. Instead, take a photo of the letter and text it to your daughter with one line: "Can you help me figure out what this means?" You don't have to explain everything. You don't have to perform competence. Just send the photo. Let her help with this one thing. She's been looking for a way in. This could be it—not her fixing you, just her helping you with a piece of paper. That's allowed.

You said you're "still here" like it's nothing. It's not nothing. It's the whole thing.

That's you asking for help and letting someone in. A few weeks ago you couldn't open the mail. Now you're texting your daughter a photo and picking up when she calls back. Notice that.

The new kid asking questions, your manager "checking in," everyone walking on eggshells—you're reading it as pity. *The widow who can't keep it together.* But here's another possibility: they don't know what to say. If they're a comfort—a way to feel him still present—that's allowed. If they're a daily wound that makes it harder to breathe—that's different. Which is it for you? What you have now—this wobbly, exhausted, going-through-the-motions version—might be what okay looks like for now. That's allowed to count.

**The grief group and the therapist:** You know. You've known for a few weeks. I'm not going to push—you'll do it when you're ready or you won't. You're not someone who can't reach for things. You're someone who reaches when you're ready, on your own timeline, in your own scared and stubborn way. The group. The therapist.
